episode_summary: This episode of "No Such Thing As A Fish" covers a range of fascinating topics, including the unique water sourcing methods of Easter Island's indigenous people, a prolific noise complainer at Dublin Airport, Emily Dickinson's lesser-known reputation as a baker, and animals that use mimicry for survival.

facts.fact: There's hardly any fresh water on Easter Island, so the indigenous people drank straight from the sea.
Last year, Dublin Airport received 13,569 noise complaints; 12,272 of those were made by one person.
In her lifetime, Emily Dickinson was better known as a baker than as a poet.
As well as a caterpillar which avoids predators by pretending to be a bird, there is a bird which avoids predators by pretending to be a caterpillar.
